newsitem.title: USA: Florida to begin citrus exports to New Zealand.
newsitem.headline: Florida to begin citrus exports to New Zealand.

text.p: Florida state citrus officials said Thursday they reached an agreement with the New Zealand government to allow fresh citrus shipments from Florida to enter New Zealand for the first time.
Previously denied access because of quarantine restrictions, shipments may soon be flowing to New Zealand from Florida groves, according to Richard Kenny, Florida Fruit Packers Association.
The agreement, negotiated through the U.S. Department of Agriculture, was finalized earlier this week.

"We've got certain pests and diseases that they certainly don't want down there and vice versa,'' Kenny said. "We exchanged disease lists and we addressed the diseases that they were concerned about and satisfied their concerns."

Florida growers had petitioned to gain access to the New Zealand market as part of the Uruguay round of GATT talks. The market represents about 3 million potential consumers. A pact over quarantine procedures was agreed to in principle last month but the details of the agreement were not finalized until Jan. 27, Kenny said.
Last year, offshore shipments of Florida citrus passed 23 million boxes.

Although the opening of the new market will not have a dramatic impact on Florida citrus exports, Kenny said the agreement will still benefit Florida growers. At this time, New Zealand officials have not requested a similar deal.
"They've got 3 million people down there so its an incremental thing. Kenny said. "It's a long way down there, but every little bit helps."

Under the agreement, fruit entering New Zealand must come from Florida groves that have been certified to be free of Caribbean fruit flies, a citrus pest that can cause extensive damage. The fruit then must pass through a series of protocols before it can be accepted.

"This has been a long time coming," said Bobby McKown, executive vice president of Florida Citrus Mutual, Florida's largest growers association. "The breakthrough in New Zealand will help to us with Australia as well. We're hammering away at all those markets."
